(In my state, New South Wales, the baby isn't officially a baby until it takes it's first gasp of air, and this can be while it's still connected to the mother).
Charchuk

For me a rule such as "Thou shall not kill" applies, as it does to the issue of capital punishment, self-defence, euthenasia.

 
 As was shown that isn't possible. No one can live up to that commandment written as it is. Even in the original form it still wasn't as all emcompassing as you may want it to be since it only commanded against the murder of Israelites and not anyone else.
 
 
All human life, bearing as it does the image of God, is sacred.

 
 Prove this statement. Even the Pope has said that the image we're suppose to be made in is spiritual, not physical. A fetus doesn't even have a mind, and the so-called soul is a fantasy.
 
 
As to women's decisions, they can't be informed if as we see here, there's debate about what exactly a foetus is. I believe it is human, others may not.

 
 Science already knows what a fetus is. And women can base their decision on facts instead of fantazy.
 
 
But it is because I see it as human that I believe that the killing of it; a human, is wrong.

 
 It maybe human, and we never said that it wasn't, but it is not a human being and thus not murder.
 
 
Oddly enough many people don't consider that if we outlaw abortions women will still have them, and richer women will have greater access to better back-yard abortionists,

 
 Of course they will since that was how it was before women got their reproductive rights.
 
 
and thus it will be poorer women who will suffer more. It's a difficult issue because of this, weighing up one person's suffering to another's.

 
 In this case you choose the fetus over the life of a person. That is what the ban on PBA will do as well to.
superbuddhaman

[But each killing of a human being is a very bad thing. There simply is no way else of looking at it, each human being is created in the image of God. In effect it's a choice between two wrongs, not a wrong and a right.]
 
 Of course the killing of a human is a bad thing. Of course it is tragic and heart-wrenching. Of course you feel strongly about it. That's normal. The implication that a respect for life can only come from a god-belief is truly insulting. I find it astoundingly pretentious of you to present, as fact, your personal superstitions and religious rhetoric. The idea that I am created in the image of a god, yet not twenty people can line up and agree on what that god is. There are so many other ways of looking at things than the siple christian ideal, I apologise for not claiming to grasp an "eternal truth"
 
 
 
 [Even if I killed a murderer I would have great remorse and would seek the forgiveness of God.]
 
 Once again, Of course the killing of a human is a bad thing. Of course it is tragic and heart-wrenching. Of course you feel strongly about it. That's normal
 
 [ God gave us a brain, and if we've come up with medicines, then good.]
 
 They don't have medicine for everything.
 
 [That's not a very Buddhist thing to say. For a Buddhist you too are being rather judgemental of another's beliefs. I recall the Dalai Lama for instance having great respect for Christianity. You've caught me just before I've gone off to bed, so I hope I don't sound angry]
 
 Let me tell you , just once, that not all people agree on everything. If you think you have me dialed because I am a buddhist... i can tell you right now, your asumptions are wrong. I try not to be too judgemental of other beliefs. What I don't like is when someone is treading on the toes of my freedom and my rights, waving a religious banner.
 I do respect christianity. I don't doubt for a minute it has actually helped at least a dozen people thoughout it's colorful history. But that doesn't mean for a minute that i have to respect you., hope I don't sound angry.
 
 [If I believe it is the truth, then I must act accordingly. For me to do otherwise is dishonest. And, also, if I help someone on the street, I do so because of my beliefs. You lean towards a negative image of this religious view of mine.]
 
 Might I suggest a thorough reading of Shakespeare's 'Othello' for what might be wrong with acting in accordance of what you think to be true. I should hope you would help some one on the street because they neede it, not with your ulterior religious motives.
 
 
 
 [Huh? The killing of a human being is wrong. Period.]
 
 Once again, Of course the killing of a human is a bad thing. Of course it is tragic and heart-wrenching. Of course you feel strongly about it. That's normal
 
 [By your own rationale; what makes a doctor more an expert on the woman's life choice (excepting when it's a medical issue). Ditto for the judge in all cases. Judges are often men anyway.]
 
 That would be my basic ingrained understanding and trust of the american judicial system. We have entrusted our judges with the responsibility of making these decisions for us. That's what they do. We trust our doctors because of the many years of training and education they accrue at our nation's medical schools. Abortion is a medical issue, silly. 
 
 
 [But as to the truth of the matter. I hold it as true that a human being is made in the image of God. I am telling you what I believe. I am not calling for women to be hung in public for their decisions, but likewise I can't remain silent. I believe that the foetus is a human and I will argue against people who believe that it's just some weird off-shoot of the mother; or that it's not a life until it takes it's first breath. (In my state, New South Wales, the baby isn't officially a baby until it takes it's first gasp of air, and this can be while it's still connected to the mother).
 [/QUOTE]
 
 I don't really care what you hold as true. You may hold it as true tha the moon is made of green cheese- I still don't think your ideas should affect laws. You are not calling for women to be hung in public for their decisions, you are just saying they have no right at all to make that decision! Nobody expects you to remain silent, no, of course not... you have every right to get involved in some stranger a half a word away's personal and private medical decisions....Let me know the next time you have a check-up...I might have an opinion on the matter.
montalban

 I find your whole tone absolutely insulting. Especially the bit about bringing all my beliefs down to the phrase mumbo jumbo. I suppose your religion is the one rational belief system
 
 I am trying to to reply insult with insult. In that mind here endeth my discussions with you.

I find your whole tone absolutely insulting. Especially the bit about bringing all my beliefs down to the phrase mumbo jumbo. I suppose your religion is the one rational belief system
 
 I am trying to to reply insult with insult. In that mind here endeth my discussions with you.

 
 
 Awwww....I didn't mean to damage your ego.... poor thing. I'm sure you do find my tone insulting... I'm sure if I had bowed to your ridiculous notions youwould have been pleased. Sorry. 
 And for the record... NO, I don't think mine is the only rational belief system, just the most rational, but that's why I chose it.... I'm sure you feel the same way about yours... that's called faith. This debate is not about faith though, it is about abortion.
 I value life very much.. in all its varying shapes and sizes. I value every aspect of life, especially the rights of the person concerned to make decisions regarding their own life and that of their children. I support a woman's right to choose on many different levels. Although I don't doubt that this is often the wrong choice to make... it is not my place to say that.
 It is my place to have compassion for my fellow beings.... I'm sorry if you can't handle that.
 Get back up there on your high horse... I'm sure your expert opinion is needed in some stranger's life.
Robbie

I have seen that you are intelligent, superbuddhaman, but I don't think I've met anyone on the board more condescending that you. Of course, its your choice, I'm not saying you can't be a jerk.
 
 What I'm curious about, though, is what does your faith say about pride? I've never met a buddist before. Do buddist's beleive in a God?...
